_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description
The Poet Biorefining-Big Stone facility is located approximately 2
 miles west of Big Stone City, South Dakota.  Poet Biorefining-Big Stone?s
 main product is denatured ethanol for use as motor vehicle fuel.
 Production at the facility was initiated in January 2002.  Poet
 Biorefining-Big Stone produces ethanol using the dry mill method.  Corn meal is
 mixed with water and a digestive enzyme to produce starch, which is cooked
 and liquefied.  The resulting mash is cooled and a secondary enzyme is
 added to convert the liquefied starch to fermentable sugars.  Yeast is
 added to the mash to ferment the sugars to ethanol.

The fermented mash (beer) contains about 10% alcohol and is distilled,
 then passed through a dehydration system to produce 200-proof anhydrous
 ethanol.  After final dehydration, the ethanol is collected in two
 2,000,000-gallon storage tanks for addition of a denaturant (natural gas
 condensate, NGC) to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption, per
 federal and state requirements.  The NGC denaturant is stored in Tank No.
 805, which has a capacity of 60,000 gallons (approximately 378,000
 pounds).  NGC is blended with the ethanol to a maximum concentration of 5%
 NGC.  The denatured ethanol is shipped from the facility in tank
 trucks and rail cars.

Chemicals Regulated Under EPA?s Chemical Accident Prevention Program
The NGC denaturant is the only CAPP/RMP regulated chemical which
exceeds the CAPP quantity thresholds for applicability of the regulation.
The CAPP/RMP regulated process consists of the NGC denaturant storage
 tank, the dentatured ethanol storage tanks, and the associated
 blending/transfer equipment and piping.  The denaturant is added to the ethanol to
 a concentration of 2% to 5%.  The greatest CAPP regulated quantity of
 denaturant in a tank, vessel or piping system is the quantity in the
 denaturant storage tank, located in the center containment area of the
 tank farm.  

Emergency Response Policy and P

rogram
Poet Biorefining-Big Stone is committed to the protection of it
 employees, the surrounding community and the environment from hazardous
 substances used in the ethanol fuel production process.  In the event of an
 emergency, Poet Biorefining-Big Stone?s Emergency Coordinator will
 direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the
 qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable
 precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling
 of materials.  There is no facility emergency response team.  Employees
 within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if
 such response does not pose a danger to their health or safety.  In the
 event of a larger release, it is the policy of Poet Biorefining-Big
 Stone to notify the Big Stone City Fire Department and evacuate all
 employees at the facility.

Accidental Release Prevention Program, and Chemical-Specific Prevention
 Steps
Poet Biorefining-Big Stone is committed to protection of the
 environment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, employee
 training and response preparation.  Public access to the facility from the
 highway is restricted by a gate.  Much of the property is fenced, limiting
 vehicle access.  The plant is fully lighted. Personnel are typically
 on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  There is a multi-camera video
 surveillance system installed at the property, and a general computer
 based alarm system.   The alarm system includes monitoring of the storage
 tanks and denaturant blending system (level control and overfill
 monitors).  The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal
 conditions, which trigger visual control panel alarm lights and audible
 alarms.  All of the facility storage tanks have secondary storage
 containment and are included in the facility Spill Prevention Control and
 Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan.

Five-Year Accident History
The facility has an excellent record w

ith regard to minimizing
 recordable and reportable accidents.  There have been no accidents since
 startup of the facility which require inclusion in the five-year accident
 history required by Subpart B of the CAPP/RMP regulation. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Poet Biorefining-Big Stone?s management team is committed to an
 on-going system of reviewing changes in available technologies and any
 previous plant incidents to identify opportunities to improve plant safety.
 New computer based maintenance software (Maximo) is being implemented
 which will include more detailed automatic scheduling and work order
 generation for all preventative maintenance inspections and tests.
